/NTgCalls/Advanced Methods/ntg_calls.xml:
ntg_calls

This function returns a list of ntg_call_struct instances, each containing information about an active group call associated with the channel or group. You should provide a buffer as an array of ntg_call_struct elements with a size matching the value returned by ntg_calls_count. The function populates this list with data for active group calls and returns the number of group calls retrieved.

Example

#include <stdint.h> #include "ntgcalls.h" int main() { uint32_t uid = ntg_init(); ... int size = ... ; // Get the size of the call list ntg_call_struct buffer[size]; ntg_async_struct future; // Initialize the async struct int result = ntg_calls(uid, buffer, size, &future); // Wait for the async operation to complete for (int i = 0; i < result; i++) { printf("Group Call %d:\n", i + 1); printf(" Chat ID: %lld\n", buffer[i].chatId); printf(" Status: %d\n", buffer[i].status); } ... // Your Code Here return 0; }

Details

int ntg_calls()
PARAMETERS ntg_call_struct* buffer The buffer that will hold the retrieved group call information.
ERROR CODES
ASYNC ERROR CODES

/NTgCalls/Build Guide.xml:
Introduction

Being a modern library, NTgCalls requires CMake 3.27+ to be built on your system, on Linux is required at least CLang 18+ and libx11-dev. We recommend using the latest versions of both CMake and CLang. Before building NTgCalls, check for pre-compiled shared libs on GitHub Releases or Python Bindings from PyPI. Building from source may be necessary if pre-compiled packages are not available.

Installing Prerequisites

Below, we will guide you through the step-by-step process of installing the prerequisites required to compile NTgCalls on your operating system.

Linux

Update the system's package list:
First, make sure you have an updated list of packages: $ sudo apt update Build Essential, libx11-dev, Clang 18 and etc:
This section provides instructions on how to install four specific packages: libx11-dev, build-essential, curl and Clang version 18. Use the following command: x86_64 ARM64 $ sudo apt install libx11-dev build-essential curl $ wget https://apt.llvm.org/llvm.sh $ sudo bash llvm.sh 18 $ sudo apt install libx11-dev build-essential curl

Windows

Install Microsoft Visual Studio 2019:
Install Microsoft Visual Studio 2019 with the C++ workload. You can download it from the official website. Download CMake Installer:
Download the CMake installer for Windows from the official website. Run Installer:
Run the downloaded CMake installer and follow the installation wizard instructions. Make sure to select the option to add CMake to the system PATH during installation.

macOS

Install Xcode Command Line Tools:
If you don't have Xcode installed, you can install the Command Line Tools separately. Open a terminal and run the following command: $ xcode-select --install Install CMake:
Open a terminal and run the following command to install CMake: $ brew install cmake

Cloning and Building

In this section, you'll learn how to clone the NTgCalls repository and build the library from source.

Cloning the Repo

To begin building NTgCalls from source, you need to clone the GitHub repository. Follow these steps to clone the repo: Change to the Directory Where You Want to Clone the Repo:
Navigate to the directory where you want to store the NTgCalls source code. You can use the `cd` command to change directories. $ cd /path/to/your/directory Clone the NTgCalls Repository:
Use the following command to clone the NTgCalls GitHub repository: $ git clone https://github.com/pytgcalls/ntgcalls.git --recursive

Compilation

Now that you have successfully installed all the required prerequisites for NTgCalls, it's time to build the library. Follow these steps to compile NTgCalls on your system. It's essential to have Python 3.8+ installed on your server.

Building Shared Library

For developers looking to use NTgCalls with C and C++, we provide C Bindings. Follow these steps to compile NTgCalls with C Bindings in either Release or Debug mode: Change Directory:
Navigate to the root directory of the NTgCalls project: $ cd /path/to/ntgcalls Generate Library:
Run the following command to generate the libraries: Debug Release # Shared $ python3 setup.py build_lib --debug # Static $ python3 setup.py build_lib --debug --static # Shared $ python3 setup.py build_lib # Static $ python3 setup.py build_lib --static

Building Python Bindings

NTgCalls offers Python Bindings, facilitating seamless integration with Python. Follow these steps to compile NTgCalls with Python Bindings: Change Directory:
Navigate to the root directory of the NTgCalls project: $ cd /path/to/ntgcalls Install Python Bindings:
Run the following command to install the Python Bindings: $ pip3 install . -U
/NTgCalls/Callback Registration.xml:
Callback Registration

Callbacks registration allows you to specify custom functions to be executed when specific events occur or conditions are met within your application. These events might include changes in call status, media state updates, or other critical moments in the NTgCalls library's operation. When registering callbacks, keep in mind that each registration replaces the previously set callback.

ntg_on_stream_end()
PARAMETERS ntg_stream_callback callback The callback function to be executed when the stream ends.

Example

#include "ntgcalls.h" ... void myStreamEndCallback(uint32_t uid, int64_t chatID, ntg_stream_type_enum type, void *data) { // Your callback logic here } ... int main() { uint32_t uid = ntg_init(); ... // Your Code Here ntg_on_stream_end(uid, myStreamEndCallback, customData); ... return 0; }

ntg_on_upgrade()
PARAMETERS ntg_upgrade_callback callback The callback function to be executed when the stream needs to update MTProto stream parameters.

Example

#include "ntgcalls.h" ... void myOnUpgradeCallback(uint32_t uid, int64_t chatID, ntg_media_state_struct mediaState, void *data) { // Your callback logic here } ... int main() { uint32_t uid = ntg_init(); ... // Your Code Here ntg_on_upgrade(uid, myOnUpgradeCallback, customData); ... return 0; }

ntg_on_connection_change()
PARAMETERS ntg_connection_callback callback The callback function to be executed when the connection state changes.

Example

#include "ntgcalls.h" ... void myOnConnectionChangeCallback(uint32_t uid, int64_t chatID, ntg_connection_state_enum state, void *data) { // Your callback logic here } ... int main() { uint32_t uid = ntg_init(); ... // Your Code Here ntg_on_connection_change(uid, myOnConnectionChangeCallback, customData); ... return 0; }

ntg_on_signaling_data()
PARAMETERS ntg_signaling_callback callback The callback function to be executed when signaling data is received.

Example

#include "ntgcalls.h" ... void myOnSignalingDataCallback(uint32_t uid, int64_t chatID, const char *data, size_t size, void *customData) { // Your callback logic here } ... int main() { uint32_t uid = ntg_init(); ... // Your Code Here ntg_on_signaling_data(uid, myOnSignalingDataCallback, customData); ... return 0; }

ntg_register_logger()
PARAMETERS ntg_log_message_callback callback

Example

#include <stdint.h> #include "ntgcalls.h" void logger(ntg_log_message_struct* message) { printf("Log message: %s\n", message->message); } int main() { ntg_register_logger(logger); ... return 0; }
/NTgCalls/Callbacks.xml:
Callbacks

Callbacks allows you to define custom behavior or actions that should be triggered in response to specific events or conditions within your application. These events could include call-related occurrences, state changes, or other interactions with the NTgCalls library.
NTgCalls.on_stream_end()

Example

... app = NTgCalls() ... def handler(chat_id: int, update: StreamType): print(chat_id, update) ... app.on_stream_end(handler)

NTgCalls.on_upgrade()

... app = NTgCalls() ... def handler(chat_id: int, update: MediaState): print(chat_id, update) ... app.on_upgrade(handler)

NTgCalls.on_connection_change()

NTgCalls.on_signaling()

/NTgCalls/Getting Started.xml:
Getting Started

This section provides documentation for the NTgCalls C API, which allows you to use NTgCalls in various programming languages, including C, C++, Go, Rust, Deno, and more. Below, you will find detailed information about the initialization and cleanup functions.

Initialization

To get started with NTgCalls in your application, you need to initialize the library using the ntg_init function. This function sets up the necessary resources and prepares NTgCalls for use. Make sure to call ntg_init before using any other NTgCalls functions.

Example

#include "ntgcalls.h" int main() { uint32_t uid = ntg_init(); ... // Your Code Here return 0; }

Cleanup

To clean up and release the resources used by NTgCalls, you should call the ntg_destroy function. This function deallocates memory and performs necessary cleanup operations. Always call ntg_destroy when you are done using NTgCalls to prevent memory leaks and resource issues.

Example

#include "ntgcalls.h" int main() { uint32_t uid = ntg_init(); ... // Your Code Here int result = ntg_destroy(uid); if (result != 0) { printf("NTgCalls cleanup failed.\n"); return 1; } return 0; }

Library Version

You can retrieve the version of the NTgCalls library currently in use using the ntg_get_version function. This function returns a string containing the version number.

Example

#include "ntgcalls.h" #include <stdio.h> int main() { char version[8]; ntg_get_version(version, sizeof(version)); printf("NTgCalls Version: %s\n", version); return 0; }

Details

int ntg_get_version() Retrieve library version
PARAMETERS char* buffer A character buffer to store the version string.
ERROR CODES
/NTgCalls/Quick Start.xml:
Quick Start

Welcome to this section, which is primarily intended for developers who are moderately experienced or seeking to perform a porting in their language using C bindings. If you are new to Python development, we strongly recommend using Py-TgCalls. However, if you fall into the aforementioned categories, you can find an example of usage with the various porting below.

Community and Official Libraries

In the following section, we present a comprehensive catalog of libraries, thoughtfully crafted by the community and officially endorsed, all of which leverage the robust capabilities of NTgCalls.

Enjoy the API

What we've just seen are simplified ports of NTgCalls. However, now let's delve deeper! In the upcoming pages, we'll explore NTgCalls in a step-by-step manner, covering how it functions, how to install it, and more. Are you feeling eager to continue? You can take a shortcut to the Call Methods section and return later to delve into more details.

/NTgCalls/Using Async.xml:
Using Async

NTgCalls starting from version 1.2.0 supports asynchronous calls to function using ntg_async_struct, which contains userData that can be used to pass data between the caller and the callback, promise that is called when the operation is completed, and error that is set when an error occurs, but by default it is set to #NTG_ASYNC_NOT_READY (-4) until the operation is completed.

Async Call in a Sync way

To make an async call in a sync way, you can use a mutex to wait for the operation to complete: #include <ntgcalls.h> #include <mutex> void onCallReady(void* data) { ((std::mutex*)data)->unlock(); } void makeAsyncCall() { ntg_async_struct asyncData; std::mutex mtx; asyncData.userData = &mtx; asyncData.promise = onCallReady; mutex.lock(); int error = ntg_pause(asyncData); if (error != 0) { // Handle error } mutex.lock(); // Async operation completed if (asyncData.errorCode != 0) { // Handle Async error } }

Async Call with custom data

You can pass custom data to the async call by using the userData field: #include <ntgcalls.h> #include <mutex> #include <iostream> struct CustomData { std::mutex* mtx; int64_t chatID; }; void onCallReady(void* data) { CustomData* customData = (CustomData*)data; customData->mtx->unlock(); std::cout << "Chat ID: " << customData->chatID << std::endl; } void makeAsyncCall() { ntg_async_struct asyncData; std::mutex mtx; CustomData data; data.mtx = &mtx; data.chatID = 1234567890; asyncData.userData = &data; asyncData.promise = onCallReady; mutex.lock(); int error = ntg_pause(asyncData); if (error != 0) { // Handle error } mutex.lock(); // Async operation completed if (asyncData.errorCode != 0) { // Handle Async error } }

/PyTgCalls/Basic Methods/Idle.xml:
Idle

This function will run indefinitely in order to block the main script execution and prevent it from exiting while having client(s) that are still running in the background. PyTgCalls works by keeping your handlers in a pool of worker threads, which run concurrently outside the main thread. Calling idle() will ensure that the client(s) remain active, by preventing the main script from ending until you decide to quit. Once a signal is received (e.g.: from CTRL+C) the function will terminate and your main script will continue.

Example

from pytgcalls import Client from pytgcalls import idle ... app1 = PyTgCalls(client1) app2 = PyTgCalls(client2) app3 = PyTgCalls(client3) ... # Set handlers up app1.start() app2.start() app3.start() idle()

Details

pytgcalls.idle() Blocks the main script execution until a signal is received.

/PyTgCalls/Basic Methods/Play.xml:
Play

This method replaces the deprecated join_group_call and change_stream methods. This method allows streaming audio or video to a group call or a private call.

Example

from pytgcalls import Client from pytgcalls import idle from pytgcalls.types import MediaStream ... app = PyTgCalls(client) app.start() ... # Call API methods app.play( -1001185324811, MediaStream( 'test.mp4', ) ) idle()

Details

PyTgCalls.play() Join in a group call or accept/request a private call to stream audio or video.
PARAMETERS config: Optional[Union[pytgcalls.types.CallConfig, pytgcalls.types.GroupCallConfig]] Additional configuration for the call.
RAISES exception pytgcalls.exceptions.CallDeclined The call was declined by the user. exception pytgcalls.exceptions.CallDiscarded The call was discarded by the user while connecting. exception pytgcalls.exceptions.AlreadyJoinedError You are attempting to join in a call you're already a part of.
/PyTgCalls/Basic Methods/Run.xml:
Run

This is a convenience method that calls start(), idle() in sequence. It makes running a client less verbose, but it is not suitable in case you want to run more than one client in a single script, since the idle() part will block all the subsequent code after starting the client.

Example

from pytgcalls import Client from pytgcalls import idle ... app = Client(client) ... # Call API decorators / MtProto decorators app.run()

Details

PyTgCalls.run() Start the client, idle the main script and finally stop the client.
RAISES

/PyTgCalls/Calling Methods.xml:
Calling Methods

At this point, we have successfully installed PyTgCalls and installed an MTProto client; we are now aiming towards the core of the library. It’s time to start playing with the API!

Basic Usage

Making API method calls with PyTgCalls is very simple. Here’s a basic example we are going to examine step by step: from pytgcalls import PyTgCalls from pytgcalls import idle from pytgcalls.types import MediaStream ... api_id = 12345 api_hash = '0123456789abcdef0123456789abcdef' ... app = PyTgCalls(client) app.start() app.play( -1001185324811, MediaStream( 'http://docs.evostream.com/sample_content/assets/sintel1m720p.mp4', ) ) idle()

Basic step-by-step

Let’s begin by importing the Client class, Stream type and idle function: Now let’s import your MTProto Client: PyrogramMod Telethon Hydrogram from pyrogram import Client from telethon import TelegramClient from hydrogram import Client Set your api_id and api_hash taken from my.telegram.org: api_id = 12345 api_hash = '0123456789abcdef0123456789abcdef' Initialize the MTProto client: PyrogramMod Telethon Hydrogram client = Client('test_session', api_id, api_hash) client = TelegramClient('test_session', api_id, api_hash) client = Client('test_session', api_id, api_hash) Initialize the PyTgCalls client: app = PyTgCalls(client) Start the PyTgCalls client: app.start() Now you can call any method you want: app.play( -1001185324811, MediaStream( 'http://docs.evostream.com/sample_content/assets/sintel1m720p.mp4', ) ) Lastly, call the idle function to keep your code running: idle()

Asynchronous Calls

In case you wish to run PyTgCalls asynchronously: import asyncio from pytgcalls import PyTgCalls from pytgcalls import idle from pytgcalls.types import MediaStream ... app = PyTgCalls(client) async def main(): await app.start() await app.play( -1001185324811, MediaStream( 'http://docs.evostream.com/sample_content/assets/sintel1m720p.mp4', ) ) await idle() asyncio.get_event_loop().run_until_complete(main())

Asynchronous step-by-step

Import PyTgCalls, AsyncIO and create an instance: import asyncio from pytgcalls import PyTgCalls from pytgcalls import idle ... app = PyTgCalls(client) Async methods can’t be executed at the top level, because they must be within an async-defined function; here, we define one, and we put our code inside it; method calls require the await keyword: async def main(): await app.start() await app.play( -1001185324811, MediaStream( 'http://docs.evostream.com/sample_content/assets/sintel1m720p.mp4', ) ) await idle() Then, we tell asyncio to call main() in async mode asyncio.get_event_loop().run_until_complete(main())
/PyTgCalls/Changelogs.xml:
Changelogs


What's new?

Private Calls: Now you can make private calls by just using a single method for also group calls, by using play(). Code Rework: The code has been reworked to improve performance, stability and to make it more readable. Async Support: NTgCalls now supports asynchronous methods for improved performance. Filters for Updates: Added filters for updates to allow for more granular control over updates, More Info. Improved Documentation: Updated documentation with more examples, new UI and comprehensive guidance.

Breaking Changes

Now methods like change_stream() and join_group_call() was removed, now you can use play() for both private, group calls and changing streams. # Change stream call_py.change_stream( -1001234567890, AudioPiped( 'input.mp4', ), )
# Join group call call_py.join_group_call( -1001234567890, AudioPiped( 'input.mp4', ), ) # Change stream call_py.play( -1001234567890, AudioPiped( 'input.mp4', ), )
# Join group call call_py.play( -1001234567890, AudioPiped( 'input.mp4', ), ) Now all listeners like on_stream_end() was unified in on_update() and with filters, for example: # On Closed Voice Chat @call_py.on_closed_voice_chat() async def on_closed_voice_chat(client: PyTgCalls, update: Update): print(update)
# On stream end @call_py.on_stream_end() async def on_stream_end(client: PyTgCalls, update: Update): print(update) from pytgcalls import filters from pytgcalls.types import ChatUpdate ... # On Closed Voice Chat @call_py.on_update(filters.chat_update(ChatUpdate.Status.CLOSED_VOICE_CHAT)) async def on_closed_voice_chat(client: PyTgCalls, update: Update): print(update)
# On stream end @call_py.on_update(filters.stream_end) async def on_stream_end(client: PyTgCalls, update: Update): print(update) Reworked GroupCall type, now is Call and now is more powerful and easy to use. Removed JoinedGroupCallParticipant and LeftGroupCallParticipant classes, now you can see the action in GroupCallParticipant class. Removed all legacy types and input stream, now is a mandatory to use MediaStream for all streams. Now ping() from Client is not anymore a coroutine, now is a normal method. Removed get_active_call() and get_call(), now is a mandatory to use calls() from Client. Renamed leave_group_call to leave_call(). Moved MediaStream flags under MediaStream.Flags instead of MediaStream. Now invite_hash, join_as and auto_start are part of GroupCallConfig instead of join_group_call. Renamed additional_ffmpeg_parameters to ffmpeg_parameters in MediaStream. For more info about breaking changes, check the Examples, if we missed something, please open an issue.

Additional Notes

We're pleased to announce that now is available an unofficial porting of NTgCalls for Rust, for more info, check the repository.

What's new?

Static Typing: PyTgCalls is now fully statically typed, ensuring that the types of each method and class are thoroughly checked. YtDlp Support: MediaStream now supports links from YouTube using YtDlp, for example: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iSbLHrrqmoM MediaStream Quality Support: MediaStream now accepts enhanced quality options for audio and video parameters. For audio, use pytgcalls.types.AudioQuality, and for video, use pytgcalls.types.VideoQuality. call_py.join_group_call( -1001234567890, MediaStream( 'input.mp4', AudioParameters.from_quality(AudioQuality.STUDIO), VideoParameters.from_quality(VideoQuality.FHD_1080p), ), ) call_py.join_group_call( -1001234567890, MediaStream( 'input.mp4', AudioQuality.STUDIO, VideoQuality.FHD_1080p, ), )

Breaking Changes

Now all raw methods like AudioParameters, VideoParameters, AudioStream, VideoStream, and Stream are all under pytgcalls.types.raw instead of pytgcalls.types. The exception class pytgcalls.exceptions.TelegramServerError is now part of ntgcalls.TelegramServerError.

Additional Notes

We're pleased to announce that pre-compiled wheels optimized for ARM64 devices are now available.

What's new?

AutoStart of Group Calls: Now GroupCalls will be started automatically if they are not started, if you want to know how to disable it, read here. Unified Stream Design: Now you can do whatever you want, streaming audio, video, both, recording the stream etc. with just one class!. # Play audio and video from and MP4 file call_py.join_group_call( -1001234567890, AudioVideoPiped( 'input.mp4', ), )
# Stream audio only from an MP4 file call_py.join_group_call( -1001234567890, AudioPiped( 'input.mp4', ), )
# Stream screen call_py.join_group_call( -1001234567890, CaptureVideoDesktop( MediaDevices.get_screen_devices()[0], ), ) # Play audio and video from and MP4 file call_py.join_group_call( -1001234567890, MediaStream( 'input.mp4', ), )
# Stream audio only from an MP4 file call_py.join_group_call( -1001234567890, MediaStream( 'input.mp4', video_flags=MediaStream.IGNORE, ), )
# Stream screen call_py.join_group_call( -1001234567890, MediaStream( MediaDevices.get_screen_devices()[0], ), )

Deprecation Notice

As we said in the last post, now PyTgCalls 0.8.6 has reached the end of life, so this update is completely incompatible with this or previous versions. We have also deprecated most of the Stream Piped methods, here's the list: AudioImagePiped AudioPiped AudioVideoPiped CaptureAudioDevice CaptureAVDesktop CaptureAVDeviceDesktop CaptureVideoDesktop VideoPiped

What's new?

NTgCalls Integration: The PyTgCalls core has been updated to use NTgCalls instead of TgCallsJS, making it more portable and eliminating overhead. Now, you only need to install ffmpeg on your machine, resulting in improved performance. Hydrogram Support: Official support for Hydrogram, a new mtproto client based on Pyrogram, providing new possibilities and enhancing the overall experience. New Documentation: Revamped documentation with improved clarity, comprehensive examples, and up-to-date guidance for developers.

Community Milestone

Thank You All: Celebrating over 100 thousand Downloads! The project has seen remarkable growth, averaging around 8,000 downloads per week since its launch. We appreciate the community's strong interest and support.

Deprecation Notice

End-of-Life (EOL) Dates: Due to changes in Pyrogram and significant time since the release of PyTgCalls 0.8.X, different versions are marked for end-of-life: 0.8.0, 0.8.1, 0.8.2, 0.8.3, 0.8.4, 0.8.5: Support ended due to outdated versions. 0.8.6: Support will continue until December 18 due to Pyrogram archiving. 0.9.X: Current Long-Term Support. 1.0.X: Latest version with high-support rate.

What's new?

Time Tracking: Added the ability to determine the time of the currently playing audio/video. For more details, check Played Time. New Errors: Introduced two new errors, UnMuteNeeded and RTMPStreamNeeded.

Changes & Bug Fixes

End of Life for Python3.6: Support for Python 3.6 has reached the end of life and is no longer maintained. Security Fix: Addressed a security issue with the ID generation process to enhance overall security. Multi-Thread Removal: Removed Multi-Thread Py-TgCalls due to no bug fixes by Node.js for over 4 years.
As we know, Google is in charge of financing Python. Due to the recent events with the Node.js situation, PyPI ran for cover, thanks to the strong collaboration between Python and the Google Open Source Security Team they offered 4000 Titan Tokens for free available only in some regions of the world. PyPI to distribute these security tokens was based on a criterion, that is; any project in the top 1% of downloads in the previous 6 months is considered critical, at the moment only 3500 projects are considered out of 350 thousand are considered as such and py-tgcalls is considered a critical project. According to statistics last month, it was downloaded 684 thousand times.

Changes & Bug Fixes

WebRTC Retry Fixes: Addressed issues with WebRTC retry for more reliable connections. Asynchronous Method Invocation: All methods, such as join_group_call, now use asyncio future, waiting for responses from Node.js asynchronously.

What's new?

Internal FFmpeg Conversion: Introduced internal FFmpeg conversion for AudioPiped, AudioVideoPiped, and AudioImagePiped for seamless multimedia handling. call_py.join_group_call( -1001234567890, AudioVideoPiped( 'input.webm', ), stream_type=StreamType().pulse_stream, ) Remote Stream Support: Added support for remote streams for more diverse streaming options. Stream Image with Audio: Added the ability to stream images with audio using AudioImagePiped. GetParticipants and OnParticipantChange: New functionalities for handling participants in group calls. Browser Constants as Headers: Added browser constants as headers for FFmpeg. Python 3.10 Support: Added compatibility with Python 3.10.

Changes & Fixes

Proportion Video Support: Added support for all proportion video formats for a more versatile video experience. Communication Fix: Addressed stderr overflow by adding a reader for improved Node.js communication. WebRTC Connection Retry: Added automatic retry if WebRTC connection fails for more reliable connections. Lighter Buffer Reader: Optimized the Buffer Reader for lighter resource usage. Multiple Ping Requests: Now supports multiple ping requests for improved responsiveness.

What's new?

Custom Exceptions: Added custom exceptions for more robust error handling. Platform Support: Added support for Windows, macOS, and Linux Arm64.

Changes & Fixes

PyTgCalls Re-Base: Code cleanup and fixes for a more streamlined and efficient codebase. Fully Async: The library is now fully asynchronous for improved performance. Communication Update: Removed the internal socket server for Node.js communication between Python, replaced with stdin and stdout. CustomAPI Renewed: CustomAPI upgraded to version 2.1 with new features and improvements. RawUpdate Enhancement: RawUpdate renewed with PyTgCalls Object Update for better handling of updates. Method Name Change: .run() is now .start() and no longer blocks code execution. Logging Update: Now logs are directed to Python Logging for improved logging capabilities. Voice Call Handling: If the stream is deleted, the userbot will exit the voice call by printing an error in RawUpdate.

What's new?

Multi-core support: PyTgCalls now supports multiple cores for enhanced performance. Remote version check: Added the ability to check for the latest version available on GitHub remotely.

Changes & Fixes

CustomAPI 2.0: Upgraded to CustomAPI version 2.0 with new features and improvements. Security Fix: Addressed a security vulnerability for a more secure experience. Function execution without Node.js Core waiting: Users can now call functions without waiting for the Node.js Core.

Changes & Fixes

Fixed PyPi builds: Fixed an issue where PyTgCalls compiled without the JavaScript core Improved join_group_call error: The join_group_call error is now more descriptive
/PyTgCalls/Client.xml:
PyTgCalls Client

You now are in the API Reference section. Here you can find detailed information about PyTgCalls API: the main Client class, all available methods, types, attributes and decorators detailed descriptions can be found starting from this page. This page is about the Client class, which exposes high-level methods for easy access to the API.

Example

from pytgcalls import PyTgCalls app = PyTgCalls(client) app.start()

Details

class pytgcalls.PyTgCalls PyTgCalls Client, the main tool for interacting with Telegram Calls.
PARAMETERS app: Union[pyrogram.Client, telethon.TelegramClient, hydrogram.Client] Pass the MTProto Client cache_duration: int Cache duration of a Full Chat query
STATIC METHODS async calls -> dict[str, Call] async group_calls -> dict[str, Call] Get all group calls async private_calls -> dict[str, Call] Get all private calls cache_peer -> Get current Telegram user ping -> int Ping of NTgCalls core async cpu_usage -> float Get the CPU usage of the current process
RAISES exception pytgcalls.exceptions.InvalidMTProtoClient You set an invalid MTProto client.

/PyTgCalls/Decorators.xml:
Decorators

While still being methods bound to the PyTgCalls class, decorators hold a special significance that justifies a dedicated page. Decorators allow you to register callback functions for handling updates in a much easier and cleaner way. All you need to do is add the decorators on top of your functions. from pytgcalls import PyTgCalls from pytgcalls.types import Update from pytgcalls import filters as call_filters ... client = # Here Your MTProto Client app = PyTgCalls(client) @app.on_update(call_filters.stream_end) async def handler(client: PyTgCalls, update: Update): print(update) app.run()

PyTgCalls Decorators


@PyTgCalls.on_update() Decorator for handling all incoming updates. When any update is received, this decorator will be triggered. PARAMETERS filters: Optional[Filters]

Example

from pytgcalls.types import Update ... app = PyTgCalls(client) ... @app.on_update() async def handler(client: PyTgCalls, update: Update): print(chat_id) ... app.run()

CustomApi Decorators

@CustomApi.on_update_custom_api() Decorator for handling incoming HTTP events. RAISES exception pytgcalls.exceptions.TooManyCustomApiDecorators You have set too many decorators.

Example

... webserver = CustomApi(client) ... @webserver.on_update_custom_api() async def handler(request: dict): print(update) ... # Add Your Code here, switch or etc. return { 'result': 'OK', } webserver.start() idle()
/PyTgCalls/Examples.xml:
Examples

This page contains example scripts to demonstrate how PyTgCalls looks like. Every script is working right away (assuming you correctly set up your credentials), meaning you can simply copy-paste them and run. The only things you have to modify are session names and target chats, where applicable. The examples listed below can be treated as building blocks for your own applications and are designed to be simple enough to give you a basic idea. Example Description additional_ffmpeg_parameters Append parameters to ffmpeg capture_mic Capture microphone custom_api Use custom API server to bind PHP or other API to PyTgCalls fifo_conversion Play a stream from fifo p2p_example Play a stream from a private call using PyTgCalls piped_audio_calls Play audio using ffmpeg for live conversion (with integrated ffmpeg) piped_image_calls Play audio and image using ffmpeg for live conversion (with integrated ffmpeg) raw_streaming Play PCM16L and RAW_VIDEO from disk remote_piped_play Play a stream from a remote link using ffmpeg for live conversion (with integrated ffmpeg) remote_stream_with_header Play a stream from a remote link using ffmpeg for live conversion (with integrated ffmpeg) with additional headers screen_sharing Screen sharing screen_sharing_mic Screen sharing with microphone simple_calls A simple example about using PyTgCalls with High Level Methods telethon_example A simple example about using PyTgCalls with Telethon video_calls Play audio and video using ffmpeg for live conversion (with integrated ffmpeg) youtube_dl Example usage of PyTgCalls with YoutubeDL
/PyTgCalls/Filters.xml:
Filters

Filters are objects that can be used to filter the content of incoming updates. Read more about how filters work.

Details

pytgcalls.filters.create() Easily create a custom filter. Custom filters give you extra control over which updates are allowed or not to be processed by your handlers.
PARAMETERS func: callable A function that accepts three positional arguments (filter, client, update) and returns a boolean: True if the update should be handled, False otherwise. The filter argument refers to the filter itself and can be used to access keyword arguments (read below). The client argument refers to the Client that received the update. The update argument type will vary depending on which Handler is coming from. Your function body can then access the incoming update attributes and decide whether to allow it or not. name: Optional[str] Your filter’s name. Can be anything you like. Defaults to "CustomFilter". **kwargs: Optional[Any] Any additional keyword arguments you want to pass to your filter function.
pytgcalls.filters.me() Filter updates for yourself.
pytgcalls.filters.stream_end() Filter updates for when a stream ends.
pytgcalls.filters.chat() Filter updates coming from one or more chats. You can use set bound methods to manipulate the chats container.
PARAMETERS chats: Union[int, str, list] Pass one or more chat ids/usernames to filter chats. Defaults to None (no chats).
pytgcalls.filters.chat_update() Filter specific type of chat updates.
PARAMETERS flags: ChatUpdate.Status Pass one or more flags to filter chat updates. pytgcalls.filters.call_participant() Filter updates for when a call participant joins, leaves or is updated.
PARAMETERS flags: Optional[GroupCallParticipant.Action] Pass one or more flags to filter call participant updates.
/PyTgCalls/Handling Updates.xml:
Handling Updates

Calling API methods sequentially is cool, but what if, for example, the list of participants changes? This page covers updates and how to handle such events in PyTgCalls. Let’s have a look at how they work.

Defining Updates

First of all, let's define what these updates are. As hinted earlier, updates are events that happen in PyTgCalls, such as joining a group call, changes in the participant list, stream ended etc. They are meant to notify you about a new specific state change. These updates are handled by registering one or more callback functions in your app using Decorators. Each handler deals with a specific event. When a matching update arrives from Telegram or NTgCalls, the registered callback function will be called back by the framework, and its body will execute.

Registering a Handler

To explain how handlers work, let's examine the one that will be in charge of handling StreamVideoEnded updates, which occur when a video stream ends. The same setup logic is shared with every type of handler, and you should not have troubles settings them up once you have learned from this section.

Using Decorators

The most elegant way to register a stream end handler is by using the on_stream_end() decorator: from pytgcalls import PyTgCalls, filters from pytgcalls.types import Update from pytgcalls.types import MediaStream ... app = PyTgCalls(client) @app.on_update(filters.stream_end) async def my_handler(client: PyTgCalls, update: Update): if isinstance(update, StreamVideoEnded): await pytgcalls.play( -1001185324811, stream=MediaStream( 'http://docs.evostream.com/sample_content/assets/sintel1m720p.mp4', ) ) app.run() The defined my_handler function, which accepts two arguments (client, update), will be executed whenever a new update arrives. You can mix def and async def handlers as much as you need, PyTgCalls will still work concurrently and efficiently regardless of what you choose.
/PyTgCalls/Install Guide.xml:
Install Guide

Being a modern Python library, PyTgCalls requires Python 3.8+ to be installed in your system. We recommend using the latest versions of both Python 3 and pip. Get Python 3 from the Python website or use your package manager. Get pip by following the instructions here. PyTgCalls only supports Python 3, starting from version 3.8.

Install PyTgCalls

The easiest way to install and upgrade PyTgCalls to its latest stable version is by using pip: $ pip3 install -U py-tgcalls

Bleeding Edge

PyTgCalls is always evolving: although new releases on PyPI are only published when a significant number of changes are added, this doesn’t mean you can’t try new features right now! In case you’d like to try out the latest PyTgCalls’ features, the GitHub repo is constantly updated with new changes; you can install the development version straight from the master branch using this command (note “master.zip” in the link): $ pip3 install -U git+https://github.com/pytgcalls/pytgcalls

Verifying

To verify that PyTgCalls is correctly installed, open a Python shell and import it. If no errors show up you are good to go. >>> import pytgcalls >>> pytgcalls.__version__ ''

Media Devices

This class offers methods to access information regarding media devices available on your system. This functionality proves valuable when you intend to stream content from either your screen or microphone.

Example

from pytgcalls import Client from pytgcalls import idle from pytgcalls.media_devices import MediaDevices ... app = PyTgCalls(client) app.start() ... # Call API methods app.play( -1001185324811, CaptureAudioDevice( MediaDevices.get_audio_devices()[0], ) ) idle()

Details

class pytgcalls.MediaDevices MediaDevices, the main tool for retrieving media devices list.
METHODS get_audio_devices() -> list[pytgcalls.DeviceInfo] Retrieve a list of available audio input devices. get_screen_devices() -> list[pytgcalls.ScreenInfo] Retrieve a list of available screen devices
/PyTgCalls/Quick Start.xml:
Quick Start

The next few steps serve as a quick start for all new Pythoneers that want to see PyTgCalls in action as quickly as possible. Let’s go!

Get PyTgCalls Real Fast

Install PyTgCalls with pip3 install -U py-tgcalls. Choose your MTProto client between PyrogramMod (ex Pyrogram), Telethon or Hydrogram. Get your own Telegram API key from my.telegram.org Open your favorite text editor and use the following: from pytgcalls import PyTgCalls from pytgcalls import idle from pytgcalls.types import MediaStream ... chat_id = -1001185324811 app = PyTgCalls(client) app.start() app.play( chat_id, MediaStream( 'http://docs.evostream.com/sample_content/assets/sintel1m720p.mp4', ) ) idle() Replace client and chat_id values with your own. Save the file as main.py. Watch PyTgCalls playing the audio file. Join our community.

Enjoy the API

That was just a brief overview that barely scratched the surface! In the following few pages of the introduction, we’ll have a much more in-depth look at what we have just done. Are you feeling eager to continue? You can take a shortcut to Call Methods and return later to learn more details.

/PyTgCalls/Using Filters.xml:
Using Filters

So far we’ve seen how to register a decorator function that executes every time an update comes from the server, but there’s much more than that to come. Here we’ll discuss filters. Filters enable a fine-grain control over what kind of updates are allowed or not to be passed in your callback functions, based on their inner details.

Single Filters

Let’s start right away with a simple example: This example will show you how to only handle updates that are an Incoming Call and ignore any other update. Filters are passed as the first argument of the decorator: from pytgcalls import filters from pytgcalls.types import ChatUpdate ... @pytgcalls.on_update(filters.chat_update(ChatUpdate.Status.INCOMING_CALL)) def on_incoming_call(client, update): print("Incoming call!", update)

Combining Filters

Filters can be used in a more advanced way by inverting and combining more filters together using bitwise operators ~, & and |: Use ~ to invert a filter (behaves like the not operator). Use & and | to combine filters together (behaves like the and and or operators). Here are some examples: This example will show you how to only handle updates that are left updates from a specific chat and ignore any other update: from pytgcalls import filters from pytgcalls.types import ChatUpdate ... @pytgcalls.on_update(~filters.chat_update(ChatUpdate.Status.LEFT_GROUP) & filters.chat(1234567890)) def on_incoming_voice_call(client, update): print("Left chat!", update) This example will show you how to only handle updates that are left updates or incoming call updates and from a specific chat: from pytgcalls import filters from pytgcalls.types import ChatUpdate ... @pytgcalls.on_update(filters.chat(1234567890) & (filters.chat_update(ChatUpdate.Status.LEFT_GROUP) | filters.chat_update(ChatUpdate.Status.INCOMING_CALL))) def on_incoming_voice_call(client, update): print("Incoming voice call or left chat!", update)
